content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The test is less difficult than it seems at first sight (especially when you don't know the game). It was fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle, the difficulty is adequate & statement is clear.
Tests are well constructed to help you check each scoring method individually.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cribbage is an outstanding card game and this is a well crafted puzzle. The logic in scoring a cribbage hand gives the puzzler multiple opportunities to practice generating combinations and the test cases cover them all. Great job Mean Dean the Hot Air Machine! 

Bonus points if you know where that last reference comes from.

I'm glad this puzzle is back! I'm still struggling with the runs spec just a bit. There are other card games where where it is not possible to reuse a single card in multiple runs. Does your spec, as written, account for a double run?
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

In this sentence: Runs: 3 or more consecutive cards by rank, 1 point for each card. Ex: 1H + 2D + 3S = 3 points, TC + JD + QS + KC = 4 points. You can only count 1 run in a hand so a run of 4 is not also 2 runs of 3.

>> I think 1H should be AH. Using 1H implies to me that 1H is a legitimate card.

>> I think this entire "Runs" spec might need to be rewritten just a bit. It is indeed possible to have 2 runs of 3 cards in the same hand... 2H 3H 3D 4S.  How about this:

Runs: A unique group of 3 or more consecutive cards by rank, 1 point for each card. If a group is a subset of a longer group, only the longer group is counted. Ex: 1H + 2D + 3S = 3 points, TC + JD + QS + KC = 4 points, 2H + 3H + 3D + 4S = 3 points for the first run of (2H, 3H, 4S) + 3 points for the second run of (2H, 3D, 4S) + 2 points for the pair of 3s = 8 points. 

In your Input section, I believe you mean to say: (The first 4 cards for the player, the 5th is the starter card)

Goal section
* Please change "nobs" to "Nobs" in the third sentence.

* I suggest to add at least one example with the steps and explanation of how the answer is calculated, because you have chosen to put just the link instead of any details of scoring.
(Compare: https://www.codingame.com/ide/puzzle/texas-holdem )

Input section
* I suggest to format A, 2, 3, 9, T, J, Q, K, H, D, C and S as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar, but remain different. Please revise the cases.

Thanks.

For 20+ years now, I've watched my dad teach his grandkids how to count cribbage hands.  What a wonderful game for secretly getting kids (and adults) to practice their math skills.

I have coded up a solution and all your test cases look great. I think your goal statement is well written and has all the necessary details. Other than my earlier suggestions, I only have one thought. I might change the output description to:

N Lines: The score for the given hand.

Cribbage hands have a correct score and I suppose a bunch of wrong scores, but there is never more than one possible correct score.
I could be wrong about this. I looked up a bunch of cribbage explanations, and none of them explained runs in a super clear way.
Thanks.  Mean Gene Okerlund!  People call me Dean the Mean Machine or Dean the Mean Green Machine all the time.

I saw Mean Gene live at the St Paul Civic center many times as a kid. Unfortunate, I left MN before a professional wrastler became governor. The only news bigger than that would have been Doug or Bob being your PM.

Double and triple runs are a thing.  It's well explained here: https://huddlearoundgames.com/how-to-count-runs-in-cribbage/

I think I will add double and triple run tests.
Thank you for that.  I have fixed my mistakes and adjusted for your suggestions.
Would you consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle (that's between the Statement section and the Tags section in the "Edit contribution" view)?
